Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Stereotypes can have profound implications for how individuals are viewed and the opportunities they have. It is often presumed that the stereotypes people hold are simple, but they are not. The stereotypes people use to understand others are often quite complex. Understanding this nuance therefore has important implications both for creating stronger empirical models of stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination processes and for reducing instances of stereotyping and discrimination. The proposed research investigates the nuanced manner in which social perceivers think about and behave towards others using information about age, sex, race, and features of the local circumstances in which people live (e.g., the availability and predictability of economic resources in their communities). This approach suggests novel ways of reducing the application of many of the most pernicious stereotypes to members of minority groups, and thus for reducing discrimination against them.

This research is grounded in life history theory, a conceptual framework from the biological sciences, which highlights the roles that age and sex, in interaction with the local ecology, play in shaping people's goals, capacities, and behavioral strategies. Life history theory can therefore be usefully applied to help explain why people so readily use age, sex, and race to understand others, and why people possess many of the specific stereotypes they do. Hypotheses developed from this framework will be tested in a series of studies, employing multiple methods including national surveys and laboratory experiments. This research expands theory in innovative, transformative ways; provides rigorous empirical tests of novel, theoretically-derived hypotheses, employing a variety of methods; suggests novel interventions for reducing the extent to which stereotypes are applied to individuals; and makes important, integrative connections between the social and biological sciences, strengthening each.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Age, sex, and race stereotypes can have profound implications for how individuals are viewed and the opportunities they have. It is often presumed that the stereotypes people hold are simple, but they are not. Rather, previous research demonstrates that the stereotypes people use to understand others are often quite complex—more complex than can be accounted for by currently dominant theories of stereotyping and prejudice. Understanding this nuance thus has important implications both for creating stronger models of stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination processes and for reducing instances of inappropriate stereotyping and discrimination.

Life history theory—a conceptual framework from the biological sciences—highlights the roles that age and sex, in interaction with the local ecology, play in shaping people’s goals, capacities, and behavioral strategies. For example, young males (human and non-human) who live in resource-scarce and unpredictable environments are more likely to be focused on short-term opportunities than are young males living in more resource-rich, predictable environments. Because age, sex, and environments shape actions, and because people want to be able to predict others’ actions, we proposed that life history theory can be usefully applied to help explain why people so readily use age, sex, and race to understand others, and why people possess many of the specific stereotypes they do. This approach also suggests novel approaches for reducing the application of many of the most pernicious stereotypes to members of minority groups, and thus for reducing discrimination against them.

A wide range of experiments and surveys demonstrated strong support for our hypotheses. For example, people have strong stereotypes about individuals from “desperation” ecologies (which are harsh and unpredictable) versus “hopeful” ecologies (which are better-resourced and predictable). For example, people from desperation ecologies are stereotyped as impulsive, present-focused, and less invested in their children, whereas people from hopeful ecologies are stereotyped as planful, future-focused, and highly invested in their children. These stereotypes are held by people of different racial, gender, and age backgrounds across the U.S. and, indeed, by people throughout the world. Moreover, because Black and White Americans are believed to live in somewhat different environments—with Black Americans viewed as more likely to live in desperation ecologies and White Americans viewed as more likely to live in hopeful ecologies—people can use race as a cue to ecology in the U.S. Indeed, Americans’ racial stereotypes track their stereotypes about these groups’ presumed home ecologies. Interestingly, however, when people have information about another’s race and home ecology, the information about ecology trumps information about race: People from hopeful ecologies, regardless of whether they are Black or White, are perceived to be planful, future-focused, and highly invested in their children, whereas people from desperation ecologies, again regardless of whether they are Black or White, are perceived as impulsive, present-focused, and less invested in their children. This is just one set of findings from the broader project; other findings point, for example, to the nuanced ways in which people hold gender stereotypes that differ greatly by age.   

With respect to intellectual merit, this research has expanded theory on age, sex, and race stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination in innovative, transformative ways; has provided rigorous empirical tests of novel, theoretically-derived hypotheses, and has done so employing a variety of methods; and has made important, integrative connections between the social and biological sciences, strengthening each. Its broader impacts include implications for novel interventions for reducing the extent to which pernicious race stereotypes are applied to individuals, and the scientific training of undergraduate and doctoral scholars—many of whom are now in doctoral programs, post-doctoral research fellowships, and tenure-track faculty positions.
